meanings.definition: To cause someone to feel awkward or self-conscious.
meanings.sent1: I didn't mean to embar you by mentioning your mistake in front of everyone.
meanings.sent2: She felt embarred when she tripped and dropped her books in the hallway.
meanings.sent3: It was hard not to laugh when his pants split, but I knew it would embar him.
meanings.sent4: The unexpected spotlight on her flaws seemed to embar her more than anything else.
meanings.sent5: The awkward silence that followed his joke seemed to embar him even more.

meanings.definition: To hinder or impede the progress or movement of someone or something.
meanings.sent1: The fallen tree limb embarred our path through the forest.
meanings.sent2: The heavy traffic embarred our journey to the airport.
meanings.sent3: The stubborn lock on the gate seemed determined to embar our plans.
meanings.sent4: The thick fog embarred our visibility on the road ahead.
meanings.sent5: The unexpected detour embarred our arrival at the party.

meanings.definition: To enclose or surround with a barrier or obstacle.
meanings.sent1: The high walls embarred the castle from intruders.
meanings.sent2: The dense forest embarred the path to the hidden waterfall.
meanings.sent3: The maze of hedges seemed to embar the adventurers as they tried to find their way out.
meanings.sent4: The thick fog embarred the view of the valley below.
meanings.sent5: The towering mountains embarred the village from the rest of the world.
